Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Social Networks, Fractal Complexity, and Parasites in Japanese Macaques
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fractals (complex patterns that are self-similar at different scales) are ubiquitous in nature and help systems remain efficient and stable, but little is known about these patterns in relation to animal behavior. This research will investigate the fractal complexity of Japanese Macaque behavior patterns in relationship to parasite infection and an animal?s social network. This collaboration offers a unique opportunity to conduct behavioral observations on Koshima Island, one of the most influential research sites in the history of animal behavior, while learning statistical methods for fractal analysis under the mentorship of Dr. Andrew Macintosh of Kyoto University. This research will advance our understanding of how internal and external factors such as health and social environment influence behavior, and how individual behavior relates to societal stability.

Fractal patterns in behavior offer deep mechanistic explanations of how animals allocate energy to specific activities, a fundamental feature of behavior linked to the ability to adapt to environmental variability or changes. To investigate how the energetic costs of parasite infection affect organizational complexity in behavior, fractal analyses will be run on discretely categorized locomotion and foraging sequences recorded during focal-follows of Japanese macaques in varying health states. In addition, to examine the relationship between individual behavior patterns and social network, data from an adjacent study will be integrated using computational network tools that reveal dominance certainty and community structure. These findings will illuminate the bigger picture of modulation between an individual?s physical condition, the core structure of individual behavior patterns, and group level organization. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My participation in this program offered a unique opportunity to conduct behavioral observations of free-ranging Japanese macaques on Koshima Island, while learning statistical methods for fractal analysis under the mentorship of Dr. Andrew Macintosh of Kyoto University. The project served as a successful pilot study for my dissertation, and forged a lasting international collaboration with the host researcher. The study was designed to characterize the organization of monkey activity patterns over time and to investigate possible internal and external constraints on this structure. Theoretically, self-affine fractal patterns in activity sequences could optimize interactions with resources or information, and such complex behavior patterns would illustrate self-regulating properties of behavior. Previous research linked gastrointestinal helminth parasites with behavioral pattern, and the present study further tested the hypothesis that the energetic strain of parasites constrains the organizational complexity of behavior in Japanese macaques.

We investigated the activity patterns of 14 adult female macaques on Koshima Island, Japan, half of which received anthelmintic treatment to induce shedding of parasites. Focal sampling was used to record activity sequences of discretely categorized locomotion of individual monkeys while they engaged in various behaviors over different terrains.  We accumulated a dataset of 56 different time series of monkey activity, consisting of 4 sequences from each of the 14 focal individuals (each sequence ranging from 17-68 minutes).  Analysis is ongoing - we are using Detrended Flucuation Analysis to estimate the fractal dimensions or scaling exponents of the time series, as well as using information metrics including entropy rate that represent the degree of randomness in a sequence. These metrics describe components of the structure of monkey activity time series, which will allow us to investigate differences between and within monkeys. Further, these analyses will provide valuable insight about the preservation of behavioral structure during data collection and will inform data collection protocols in future studies.

Over the course of this program, my skills conducting field research drastically improved. I maintained a remote campsite alone on an island, living “off the grid” for periods of time. I followed monkeys across rugged terrain during all weather types while collecting behavioral data, and learned how to collect and store fecal samples. In addition, my knowledge about the variability in social structure and behavioral repertoire of different macaque species expanded greatly. My analytical skills improved substantially, through organizing my own data set and running complexity analyses.  Finally, through my participation in two primatology conferences in Japan and my time spent at the Primate Research Institute I was able to interact with world-renowned primatologists, and make connections with other students from around the world.
